author: Canaltech
title: Pais poderão proteger seus filhos de comentários no YouTube
text:
Pais e responsáveis agora contam com mais uma ferramenta para supervisionar e dar mais segurança aos seus filhos no
YouTube
. Nesta quarta-feira (10), a plataforma de streaming
anunciou uma configuração para impedir que crianças escrevam novos comentários em vídeos.
-
Como usar o Controle Parental no celular e computador
-
Como ajustar um celular para uma criança | Guia Prático
YouTube amplia controle parental
A nova opção foi divulgada em uma página de suporte do serviço com recursos ainda em fase Beta para o controle parental. No comunicado, o
"Adolescentes e pré-adolescentes poderão ler comentários quando seus pais escolherem a configuração de conteúdo 'Explorar mais' ou 'A maior parte do YouTube'. Os comentários permanecerão ocultos na configuração de conteúdo 'Explorar'", explicou a empresa.
-
Podcast Canaltech: de segunda a sexta-feira, você escuta as principais manchetes e comentários sobre os acontecimentos tecnológicos no Brasil e no mundo. Links aqui:
https://canaltech.com.br/podcast/
-
A medida é bem simples: quando ativado, o recurso impede que as crianças e adolescentes escrevam novos comentários em vídeos ou participem dos bate-papos ao vivo. No lugar, eles conseguem apenas visualizar as interações, já que continuam visíveis nos conteúdos.
Pais podem controlar a restrição
Por outro lado, tudo isso é gerenciável. Através das configurações de controle parental do YouTube, os responsáveis conseguem liberar a redação de novos comentários quando quiser, por exemplo. Da mesma forma, dá para desativar tudo de uma só vez.
Contudo, ainda não está claro se o recurso foi liberado no Brasil ou se ainda será distribuído. Nos que realizamos, não conseguimos bloquear a publicação de novos comentários em contas supervisionadas.
Procurado pelo Canaltech , o YouTube não informou se o serviço já está disponível ou ainda será lançamento no Brasil.
Leia a matéria no
Canaltech
.
Trending no Canaltech:
-
Instagram vai borrar nudes enviados para adolescentes
-
Asteroide do tamanho de carro passa pela Terra nesta quinta (11)
-
Engenheiro desmonta Cybertruck e fica chocado com a bateria
-
O filme do Silvio Santos usou a mesma fonte da Sega?
-
Vídeo da SpaceX mostra eclipse solar visto do espaço
-
Wolverine admite fraqueza perturbadora sobre seu fator de cura

author: Resumen Latinoamericano
title: Brasil. Con bombas, Policía Militar de Sao Paulo reprime ocupación del MST de planta responsable de la muerte de 235 mil peces
text:
Por Gabriela Moncau, Brasil de Fato / Resumen Latinoamericano, 9 de abril de 2025.
En la zona se encontraban vehículos de la Policía Local y de la Guardia Civil Municipal, sobre la que sobrevolaba un helicóptero.
Cerca de 400 familias del Movimiento de los Trabajadores Sin Tierra (MST) fueron expulsadas violentamente, en la mañana de este lunes (7), de un área de la Usina Azucarera São José S/A Álcool e Açúcar, en Rio das Pedras (SP), donde intentaban instalar un campamento. Perteneciente al Grupo Farias, la empresa fue multada con R$ 18 millones por la Compañía Ambiental del Estado de São Paulo (Cetesb), por provocar la muerte, en julio de 2024, de alrededor de 235 mil peces en el río Piracicaba.
Al menos quince vehículos de la Policía Militar (PM) y dos de la Guardia Civil Municipal se encontraban en la zona, sobre la que sobrevolaba un helicóptero de la PM. Portando escopetas calibre .12, los policías pidieron a los trabajadores sin tierra que despejaran un camino, que ya estaba abierto, para el paso de camiones. Luego dieron cinco minutos para desmontar el campamento. Antes de que los militantes pudieran desmantelar las estructuras del lugar, agentes armados iniciaron la represión con bombas y sin presentar orden judicial.
Una mujer que estaba muy cerca de la explosión de una de las bombas inhaló el humo, enfermó y tuvo que ser subida al autobús del grupo de los sin tierra. Todavía no hay información sobre el estado de salud del activista.
La ocupación, que inició la madrugada de este lunes, se enmarca en la Jornada Nacional de Lucha en Defensa de la Reforma Agraria. Más conocida como Abril Rojo , la principal movilización anual del MST en 2025 tiene como lema “Ocupar para alimentar a Brasil”. Debajo del cartel a la entrada de la planta, los trabajadores sin tierra colocaron tres pancartas, entre ellas: “¿Dónde están los peces en el río? La Planta São José los destruyó”. En el terreno, las familias del MST encontraron una gran cantidad de insecticidas y pesticidas. Entre ellos, Engeo Pleno: un producto fabricado por Syngenta, prohibido en Europa y asociado a la muerte de las abejas.
“La Constitución prevé la asignación de áreas afectadas por delitos ambientales a los efectos de la realización de la reforma agraria”, destaca una nota de la dirección estatal del MST, al explicar la elección del área ocupada. Además de denunciar públicamente el impacto del modelo de producción de la planta, la ocupación pretendía “exigir que las tierras del Grupo Farias se utilicen para el asentamiento de familias. Además del delito ambiental, la empresa tiene deudas, lo que demuestra la insostenibilidad de la agroindustria”, afirma el comunicado.
La policía destruye las estructuras del campo – Gabriela Moncau/Brasil de Fato A Brasil de Fato , Marcio Santos, de la dirección nacional del MST en São Paulo, reforzó que el movimiento ve las acciones de la Policía Militar como “extremadamente ilegales”. “No hubo embargo ni acción legal. Simplemente llegaron con determinación política, con la instrucción de no tolerar una ocupación legítima en ese lugar”, dijo.
“Hoy se produjo otro episodio vergonzoso de la policía de Tarcísio [de Freitas, gobernador de São Paulo], que utiliza todo su aparato represivo para reprimir a los trabajadores que se manifiestan justamente en defensa de la reforma agraria y contra los crímenes ambientales”, añadió el dirigente, destacando también que la planta ocupada “le debe millones al gobierno”.
Junto al cuerpo de guardia de la Planta São José, el MST develó la pancarta con el lema del día de lucha de abril de 2025 – Gabriela Moncau / Brasil de Fato Contaminación sin precedentes El derrame de melaza de caña de azúcar atribuido por la Cetesb a la Planta São José mató cerca de 50 toneladas de peces. Según la investigación del organismo ambiental, la contaminación se inició en el arroyo Tijuco Preto, afluente del río Piracicaba, y recorrió aproximadamente 70 kilómetros hasta llegar al Área de Protección Ambiental de Tanquã, región apodada el “mini Pantanal de São Paulo”. El episodio fue considerado el mayor desastre ambiental jamás registrado en el río Piracicaba. Según Cetesb, la inspección realizada en 2024 a la planta detectó una situación de “descontrol” en el flujo de líquidos y fugas en los tanques de almacenamiento.
Brasil de Fato contactó a Usina São José y hasta el momento de publicar este artículo no recibió respuesta. Si hay una respuesta, se actualizará el texto.
El caso del derrame de residuos muestra, en opinión de Jelson*, también coordinador del campamento, “cómo el agronegocio, no sólo de la caña de azúcar, sino de sus diversas ramas, es altamente tóxico y destructivo”.
“Esta zona no cumple su función social”, destaca el trabajador sin tierra. “Por eso presentamos esta denuncia y exigimos que se cumpla nuestra agenda de cobro y expropiación de esta zona, sin indemnización por el delito ambiental”, argumenta. Tras el desalojo, los sin tierra realizaron una manifestación en la plaza central de la ciudad de Piracicaba (SP).
*Se han cambiado los nombres para proteger la identidad de los entrevistados.
Editado por: Nathallia Fonseca

author: Addison Perry
title: Starbucks Takes Bold Steps Towards a Sustainable Coffee Future - Investors Hangout
text: Starbucks Takes Bold Steps Towards a Sustainable Coffee Future [Addison Perry](https://investorshangout.com/profile/view?id=79055)Updated: 10-03-2024 04:51 PM Starbucks Implements New Strategies for Coffee Sustainability Starbucks has announced significant advancements in its coffee innovation efforts, aimed at enhancing sustainability and protecting the future of coffee. The company is expanding its collaborative coffee innovation network, which aims to connect farmers from diverse global regions with the resources they need. This initiative builds on the pioneering agronomy innovation established at Hacienda Alsacia, Starbucks' first company-operated coffee farm. The addition of new farms in Guatemala and Costa Rica, along with future plans for investment in Africa and Asia, emphasizes the company’s commitment to global coffee sustainability. Collaborating for a Sustainable Vision Michelle Burns, the Executive Vice President of Global Coffee and Sustainability at Starbucks, highlighted the company's support for over 450,000 farms producing premium Arabica coffee. Starbucks’ dedication to these farmers and their communities speaks volumes about its commitment to a sustainable coffee future. The company’s strategy revolves around developing on-farm interventions, sharing seeds, and disseminating research and practices to help coffee producers address the effects of climate change. Challenges Facing Coffee Production Starbucks plays a vital role in the coffee industry by sourcing an impressive three percent of the world's coffee solely from Arabica beans. However, climate change poses significant threats, affecting the availability and quality of coffee globally. Challenges such as rising temperatures, drought, and diseases like coffee leaf rust are negatively impacting productivity and the livelihoods of farmers. Starbucks recognizes these challenges and is taking proactive steps to mitigate their effects. Innovating for the Future At Hacienda Alsacia, efforts are underway to counteract climate change's impact. Best practices have been developed to enhance profitability for coffee growers while producing the next generation of disease-resistant coffee varieties. As part of their commitment, Starbucks has undertaken the distribution of climate-friendly coffee trees, with nearly 90 million trees distributed to date, in line with their goal of reaching 100 million by 2025. The establishment of additional coffee innovation farms will further advance research capabilities and address climate threats more effectively. Research and Development Across the Coffee Belt The newly established farms in Costa Rica and Guatemala are expected to explore hybrid coffee varieties, focusing on different elevations and soil conditions. These farms will also leverage modern technologies, including mechanization and drones, to tackle labor shortages experienced by farmers in LatAm. The efforts in Guatemala are particularly pivotal as they replicate conditions faced by smallholder farmers, ensuring that effective solutions are developed for real-world challenges. Global Investment in Coffee Innovation Starbucks is committed to further investments across Africa and Asia, thereby establishing a broad coffee innovation network that spans the three primary coffee-growing regions: Latin America, Africa, and Asia Pacific. This diverse network will allow Starbucks to study various cultural practices, landscapes, and farming methods, all of which contribute to the exquisite flavors of coffee. Research emanating from these innovation farms will be reinforced by Starbucks' existing Farmer Support Centers and model farms, enabling practical applications of new knowledge. Continuous Learning and Support Through a comprehensive approach that includes sustainability learning labs, Starbucks aims to foster ongoing innovation and education among coffee farmers. These initiatives are essential for enhancing coffee productivity and quality while equipping farmers with the requisite knowledge and tools necessary to adapt to evolving climatic conditions. Final Thoughts on Coffee Sustainability As Starbucks forges ahead with its coffee innovation farms, the vision is clear: create a sustainable future for coffee cultivation everywhere. This transformative journey not only seeks to enhance the quality and quantity of coffee but also empowers farmers on multiple fronts—socio-economically and environmentally. Frequently Asked Questions What is Starbucks' recent announcement about coffee sustainability? Starbucks has expanded its coffee innovation network by adding new farms in Guatemala and Costa Rica, focusing on sustainable coffee production amid climate challenges. How does Starbucks support coffee farmers? Starbucks collaborates with over 450,000 farms, providing resources, research, and best practices to ensure a sustainable coffee future. What are the main threats to coffee quality? Climate change poses serious threats, including rising temperatures, drought, and diseases, affecting the productivity and quality of coffee crops. What initiatives is Starbucks implementing at Hacienda Alsacia? At Hacienda Alsacia, Starbucks focuses on developing disease-resistant coffee strains and sharing best cultivation practices with farmers globally. What are the future plans for Starbucks' coffee farms? Starbucks plans further investments in Africa and Asia to enhance its coffee innovation network and research capabilities, ensuring better sustainability practices. author: financialcontent.com
title: Clearview Roofing & Construction: Install a New Roof in the Winter in Long Island NY | FinancialContent Business Page
text:
LONG ISLAND, NY / ACCESSWIRE / Ferary 15, 2024 / Clearview Roofing & Construction has announced their open services for the winter months. For Long Island and Queens residents, December and January bring freezing weather and snow. Clearview is offering their services throughout the winter months, including melting snow off roofs and roof repairs.
Clearview, which operates as both a roofing and full construction company, specializes in shingle roofing, TPO and EPDM Rubber Flat roofing, slate roofing, leak repairs and all the interior restoration involved after a water related event.
Chris Feniello, Managing Partner of Clearview, explains how to prepare homes and buildings for the colder months. "We certainly have to deal with colder temperatures in December and January," says Feniello. "and it is true you have to take precaution and proper preparations in colder months, but it can be done for sure."
"It is important that shingles are not frozen and are pliable, so we leave them in the sun until we are ready to nail," says Feniello. "It is also important for a homeowner to know that in the colder temperatures, as it will take longer for the singles to lay down and cure. If after a week of sun, a homeowner notices a shingle or two has not laid down, we can manually seal it with flashing cement, which is a manufacturer recommendation."
For the coming winter months, New York residents are encouraged to utilize Clearview's roofing services for melting snow off their roof to prevent ice dams, which can seep under shingles and cause damage to ceilings, walls and other structures inside the home. Despite the cold weather, Clearview is experienced in taking precautions when it comes to fulfilling roofing services during the winter.
"We install heater cables that are turned on by a switch within the home if homeowners have homes that are prone to Ice Dams. Ice Dams, which occur when snow buildup melts and then refreezes, can be avoided with our heater cables placed in a zig-zag formation on the roof."
Long Island and Queens residents may still turn to Clearview for any of their construction or roofing necessities, and as the company continues to grow, their volume of insurance restoration jobs has also expanded. "We have all the mitigation equipment necessary to handle these insurance related claims, like air movers, air scrubbers and power vacuums to remove water out of basements from flooding or pipe burst events," says Chris Feniello. "We have serviced many homeowners with their insurance claims and we feel that the south shore is in need of these services as well."
Clearview is big on safety and accountability. There is such a thing as too cold to lay a roof, though for emergency situations, the company offers their services so long as it's above freezing temperatures. "If there is an emergency, we can utilize warmers to warm the shingles if necessary. Generally, as soon as it's below 30 degrees, which traditionally ends up being the month of February in Long island, we don't roof homes. However, if it's 30 in the morning but warms up to 40 degrees during the day, that is considered very acceptable working conditions.
To take precautions for the winter months and the freezing temperatures, Clearview encourages Long Island residents to seek their services sooner rather than later. They hope to continue fulfilling orders throughout the winter to those that require a roof replacement as soon as possible.
About the Company:
Clearview Roofing & Construction is a family-owned Long-Island roofing company that first started in 1961. For the past few decades, they have provided Long Island and Queens communities with a myriad of efficient services for an affordable price. Their current locations include offices in Port Washington, Huntington and Rockville Centre, all of Nassau, Suffolk and Queens counties.
To get a free on-site estimate or request a quote, contact Clearview Roofing & Construction through their website at https://longislandroofs.com/ or contact:
